Robert Watkins <yahoo@...> wrote:
> I'd rather have a facility to wrap the test suite in an
> arbitary decorator than to have hardcoded suiteSetup and
> suiteTeardown methods...

I can see both your and Cedric's point.

However... as far as I remember past questions regarding suiteSetup and
suiteTearDown on this list, most people wanted that for "optimizing"
their tests. Usually that indicated they weren't really unit-testing.

By asking here, they were pointed in a direction of better isolating
their objects under test. Even though I wouldn't consider the need for
suiteSetUp() a smell, it's IMHO an area for closer investigation.

Therefor, in the long run, I agree with Robert Watkins in saying
that you can do everything with a decorator and that's enough.
If you are experienced enough with JUnit to write the decorator, you
hopefully also know whether you really need to.

I consider it a child safety catch.

Cheers,

Robert
